sentences.sentence: We must now go back to Uncle Andrew.
His poor old heart went pit-a-pat( 扑通扑通地 ) as he staggered( 踉跄 ) down the attic( 阁楼 ) stairs( 楼梯 ) and he kept on dabbing( 轻拭 ) at his forehead with a handkerchief.
When he reached his bedroom, which was the floor below, he locked himself in.
And the very first thing he did was to grope( 搜寻 ) in his wardrobe( 衣柜 ) for a bottle and a wine-glass which he always kept hidden there where Aunt Letty could not find them.
He poured himself out a glassful( 一杯的容量 ) of some nasty( 难闻的 ), grown-up( 适于成年人的 ) drink and drank it off at one gulp( 一大口 ). Then he drew a deep breath.
“Upon my word,” he said to himself. “I’m dreadfully( 非常地 ) shaken. Most upsetting! And at my time of life!”
He poured out a second glass and drank it too; then he began to change his clothes.
You have never seen such clothes, but I can remember them.
He put on a very high, shiny, stiff( 硬邦邦的 ) collar of the sort that made you hold your chin( 下巴 ) up all the time.
He put on a white waistcoat( 马甲 ) with a pattern on it and arranged his gold watch chain across the front.
He put on his best frock-coat( 男礼服大衣 ), the one he kept for weddings and funerals.
He got out his best tall hat and polished it up.
There was a vase of flowers (put there by Aunt Letty) on his dressing table; he took one and put it in his button-hole.
He took a clean handkerchief (a lovely one such as you couldn’t buy today) out of the little left-hand drawer and put a few drops of scent( 香水 ) on it.
He took his eye-glass, with the thick black ribbon( 丝带 ), and screwed( 戴上 ) it into his eye; then he looked at himself in the mirror.
Children have one kind of silliness, as you know, and grown-ups( 成年人 ) have another kind.
At this moment Uncle Andrew was beginning to be silly in a very grown-up( 成年人的 ) way.
Now that the Witch( 女巫 ) was no longer in the same room with him he was quickly forgetting how she had frightened him and thinking more and more of her wonderful beauty.
He kept on saying to himself, “A damn fine woman, sir, a damn fine woman. A superb( 极好的 ) creature.”
He had also somehow managed to forget that it was the children who had got hold of this “superb( 极好的 ) creature”:
he felt as if he himself by his Magic had called her out of unknown worlds.
“Andrew, my boy,” he said to himself as he looked in the glass, “you’re a devilish( 非常 ) well preserved( 保养 ) fellow for your age. A distinguished-looking( 长相不凡的 ) man, sir.”
You see, the foolish old man was actually beginning to imagine the Witch( 女巫 ) would fall in love with him.
The two drinks probably had something to do with it, and so had his best clothes.
But he was, in any case, as vain( 自负的 ) as a peacock( 孔雀 ); that was why he had become a Magician.
He unlocked the door, went downstairs( 向楼下 ), sent the housemaid( 女佣 ) out to fetch a hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ) (everyone had lots of servants in those days) and looked into the drawing-room.
There, as he expected, he found Aunt Letty. She was busily mending a mattress( 床垫 ).
It lay on the floor near the window and she was kneeling( 跪下 ) on it.
“Ah, Letitia, my dear,” said Uncle Andrew, “I—ah—have to go out. Just lend me five pounds or so, there’s a good gel( 女孩 ).” (“Gel( 姑娘 )” was the way he pronounced girl.)
“No, Andrew, dear,” said Aunty Letty in her firm, quiet voice, without looking up from her work. “I’ve told you times without number that I will not lend you money.”
“Now pray don’t be troublesome( 令人头疼的 ), my dear gel( 姑娘 ),” said Uncle Andrew. “It’s most important. You will put me in a deucedly( 非常 ) awkward( 尴尬的 ) position if you don’t.”
“Andrew,” said Aunt Letty, looking him straight in the face, “I wonder you are not ashamed to ask me for money.”
There was a long, dull( 无聊的 ) story of a grown-up( 成年人的 ) kind behind these words.
All you need to know about it is that Uncle Andrew, what with “managing dear Letty’s business matters for her,” and never doing any work,
and running up large bills for brandy( 白兰地 ) and cigars (which Aunt Letty had paid again and again) had made her a good deal poorer than she had been thirty years ago.
“My dear gel( 姑娘 ),” said Uncle Andrew, “you don’t understand. I shall have some quite unexpected expenses today.
I have to do a little entertaining( 招待 ). Come now, don’t be tiresome( 烦人的 ).”
“And who, pray, are you going to entertain( 招待 ), Andrew?” asked Aunt Letty.
“A—a most distinguished( 尊贵的 ) visitor has just arrived.”
“Distinguished( 尊贵的 ) fiddlestick( 胡扯 )!” said Aunt Letty. “There hasn’t been a ring at the bell for the last hour.”
At that moment the door was suddenly flung( 猛力推开 ) open.
Aunt Letty looked round and saw with amazement( 惊讶 ) that an enormous( 巨大的 ) woman, splendidly( 华丽地 ) dressed, with bare( 裸露的 ) arms and flashing eyes, stood in the doorway( 门口 ).
It was the Witch( 女巫 ).
“Now, slave, how long am I to wait for my chariot( 双轮马车 )?” thundered the Witch( 女巫 ).
Uncle Andrew cowered( 畏缩 ) away from her.
Now that she was really present, all the silly thoughts he had had while looking at himself in the glass were oozing out( 慢慢渗出 ) of him.
But Aunt Letty at once got up from her knees and came over to the center of the room.
“And who is this young person, Andrew, may I ask?” said Aunt Letty in icy tones( 语气 ).
“Distinguished( 尊贵的 ) foreigner—v-very important p-person,” he stammered( 结结巴巴地说 ).
“Rubbish!” said Aunt Letty, and then, turning to the Witch( 女巫 ), “Get out of my house this moment, you shameless hussy( 荡妇 ), or I’ll send for the police.”
She thought the Witch( 女巫 ) must be someone out of a circus( 马戏团 ) and she did not approve( 赞成 ) of bare( 裸露的 ) arms.
“What woman is this?” said Jadis. “Down on your knees, minion( 奴才 ), before I blast( 毁灭 ) you.”
“No strong language in this house if you please, young woman,” said Aunt Letty.
Instantly, as it seemed to Uncle Andrew, the Queen towered up to an even greater height.
Fire flashed from her eyes: she flung( 急伸，猛动 ) out her arm with the same gesture and the same horrible-sounding( 听起来可怕的 ) words that had lately turned the palace-gates( 宫殿大门 ) of Charn to dust.
But nothing happened except that Aunt Letty, thinking that those horrible( 可怕的 ) words were meant to be ordinary English, said:
“I thought as much. The woman is drunk. Drunk! She can’t even speak clearly.”
It must have been a terrible moment for the Witch( 女巫 ) when she suddenly realized that her power of turning people into dust,
which had been quite real in her own world, was not going to work in ours.
But she did not lose her nerve( 勇气 ) even for a second.
Without wasting a thought on her disappointment,
she lunged( 冲 ) forward, caught Aunt Letty round the neck and the knees, raised her high above her head as if she had been no heavier than a doll, and threw her across the room.

While Aunt Letty was still hurtling( 疾飞 ) through the air, the housemaid( 女佣 ) (who was having a beautifully exciting morning) put her head in at the door and said, “If you please, sir, the hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 )’s come.”
“Lead on, Slave,” said the Witch( 女巫 ) to Uncle Andrew.
He began muttering( 嘀咕 ) something about “regrettable violence—must really protest( 反抗 ),” but at a single glance from Jadis he became speechless.
She drove him out of the room and out of the house;
and Digory came running down the stairs( 楼梯 ) just in time to see the front door close behind them.
“Jiminy( 天呀 )!” he said. “She’s loose( 不受束缚的 ) in London. And with Uncle Andrew. I wonder what on earth is going to happen now.”

“Oh, Master Digory,” said the housemaid( 女佣 ) (who was really having a wonderful day), “I think Miss Ketterley’s hurt herself somehow.” So they both rushed into the drawing-room to find out what had happened.
If Aunt Letty had fallen on bare( 光的 ) boards or even on the carpet, I suppose all her bones would have been broken: but by great good luck she had fallen on the mattress( 床垫 ).
Aunt Letty was a very tough( 强壮的 ) old lady: aunts often were in those days.
After she had had some sal volatile( 提神药 ) and sat still for a few minutes, she said there was nothing the matter with her except a few bruises( 伤痕 ).
Very soon she was taking charge of the situation.
“Sarah,” she said to the housemaid( 女佣 ) (who had never had such a day before), “go around to the police station at once and tell them there is a dangerous lunatic( 疯子 ) at large.
I will take Mrs. Kirke’s lunch up myself.” Mrs. Kirke was, of course, Digory’s mother.
When Mother’s lunch had been seen to, Digory and Aunt Letty had their own. After that he did some hard thinking.

article_info.previous: Uncle Andrew第一眼看见Jadis，就被她的气场给征服了，立马唯她马首是瞻，可孩子们并不认为把女王带回现实世界是个好主意。

article_info.share_words: At the moment the door was suddenly flung open. Aunt Letty looked round and saw with amazement that enormous woman, splendidly dressed, with bare arms and flashing eyes, stood in the doorway. It was the Witch.

question.cn: Uncle Andrew回到卧室后做了什么？
question.en: After going back to the bedroom, what did Uncle Andrew do?

analysis: 文中提出“He began to change his clothes. You have never seen sun clothes, but I can remember them…Then he looked at himself in the mirror.”由此可见，Uncle Andrew回到自己的卧室后， 他收拾打扮了自己。因此选C。

question.cn: Uncle Andrew认为女王是个怎样的女人？
question.en: What did Uncle Andrew think of the Queen?

options.en: Uncle Andrew thought she was a fine woman.
Uncle Andrew thought she was an evil woman.
Uncle Andrew thought she was a lazy woman.

analysis: 文中提到“He kept on saying to himself, a damn fine woman, sir, a damn fine woman. A superb creature.”由此可知Uncle Andrew认为女王是个漂亮的女人。因此选A。

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Anderw要打扮自己？
question.en: Why did Uncle Andrew dress himself up?

options.cn: 他认为女王会教他一些魔法。
options.en: He thought the Queen would teach him some magic.
He thought the Queen would fall in love with him.

options.cn: 他认为女王会请他吃饭。
options.en: He thought the Queen would treat him.

analysis: 文中提到“You see, the foolish old man was actually beginning to imagine the Witch would fall in love with him.”由此可知，Uncle Andrew盛装打扮的原因是他认为也许女王会爱上他。因此选B。

question.en: Who was Uncle Andrew borrowing money from？

analysis: 文中提到“Ah, Letitia, my dear…I have to go out. Just lend me five pounds or so, there’s a good gel.”由此可知，Uncle Andrew是找Aunty Letty借钱。因此选C。

question.cn: 为什么Aunty Letty不借钱给Uncle Andrew?
question.en: Why didn’t Aunty Letty lend some money to Uncle Andrew?

options.cn: 因为她把钱存在银行里。
options.en: Because Aunty Letty saved her money in the bank.
Because Aunty Letty ran out of money.
Because Uncle Andrew wasted lots of money.

analysis: 文中提到“There was a long, dull story of a grown-up kind behind these words. All you need to know about it is that Uncle Andrew… and running up large bills for brandy and cigars…”由此可知，Aunty Letty不借钱给Uncle Andrew的原因是他乱花钱，让Aunty Letty变的很穷。因此选C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第27天
